snippet: The argument for the cost savings from universal health coverage makes some intuitive sense, but it’s not backed up by research.
abstract: The Upshot; government actuaries at Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services estimate that health spending jumped by 5.5 percent in 2014, when millions of people first obtained insurance under Affordable Care Act; rise would be biggest country has experienced in five years, contradicting idea that expanded coverage will save system money.
lead_paragraph: The argument for the cost savings from universal health coverage makes some intuitive sense, but it’s not backed up by research.

headline.print_headline: Conventional Wisdom Clashes With Data on Health Care Savings
headline.main: No, Giving More People Health Insurance Doesn’t Save Money

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
